channel.title: Script manager and Random manager
channel.description:
I'm working on a very small project, not what you may have guessed by the title, however the project does call for a "ScriptManager" and "RandomManager".
My idea for handleing the Script was simple. Class extends Script, abstract class Script contains method run(), application loads class file and executes run() in a new Thread.
The big reason I am posting, is to see if there is a more efficent way to do this.
As for randoms, I'm on the wall. Do I have them all running in 1 thread, doing checks at different intervals. Or have them all in seperate threads. I'm not sure.
In both cases, whats the most CPU-efficent, and pretty solution?

item.title: Script manager and Random manager
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

How I handle it in cherokee is just have a Script manager, which manages scripts that run in their own thread, and anti-random(s) would just be their own script.

Read full topic

item.title: Script manager and Random manager
item.dc:creator: @Nader_H.I.M Nader[H.I.M]
item.description:
@Nader_H.I.M wrote:

Mopman:

That depends what you’re using randoms for, if you’re using them for any “exception” type event that happens (logouts etc) you may well indeed have multiple running at the same time

Still you can add a logout event or Some Similar thing to the the same anti-random thread.

Read full topic

item.title: Script manager and Random manager
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

an event based finite state machine would be the best way to do everything

item.title: Script manager and Random manager
item.dc:creator: @Nader_H.I.M Nader[H.I.M]
item.description:
@Nader_H.I.M wrote:

oksuper_:

Ace wrote a fine state-based approached system to script and random managing for Arcanum, you may wanna just ask him for some tips

its not that fine , it consist of 3 basic looping speeds recognized as a state object.

Anyhow, i wrote simple one for my new bot, wich works Fine logically , and here it is:

The Engine:

package net.Arms.Utils.ScriptEngine;

/**
 *
 * @author Nader
 */
public class Engine {

   public Scriptable c;

    public Engine(Scriptable c) {
        this.c = c;
    }
    public  boolean pause;
    public  boolean stop;

    public void Stop() {
        stop = true;
    }

    public void Pause() {
        pause = true;
    }

    public void doRun() {
    
        try {
            
    Loop  :   while (true) {
             
             if (pause) {
            
                  Thread.sleep(700);
             }else
                if (c.MainLoop() > -1) {
                    
                    Thread.sleep(c.MainLoop());
                  
                } else if (c.MainLoop() <= -1 || stop) {
                    break  Loop;

                }
            }
        } catch (Exception e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
}

The Abstract Scriptable Class"

package net.Arms.Utils.ScriptEngine;

/*
 * To change this template, choose Tools | Templates
 * and open the template in the editor.
 */

/**
 *
 * @author Nader
 */
public abstract class Scriptable{

   public abstract int MainLoop();

}

A Script Example:

package net.Arms.Utils.ScriptEngine;
import net.Arms.Core.Skeleton;
/**
 *
 * @author Nader
 */

public class ScriptTest extends Scriptable {

public ScriptTest(Skeleton s){
super(s);
}
 public int MainLoop(){
 System.out.println("Sleep Test");
  return 3000;

}
}

-> In The Main Core Run Something like : new Engine(ScriptsName).doRun();

Speaking about the anti-random’s management , i prefer you just run one Thread that contains all cases since you’ll never have multi randoms at one time per one bot’s instance, and then Whenever you face some random, you just trigger the pause method of the engine’s instance corresponding to its bot’s instance, and finally, when you press the stop button, you trigger the stop method, that’s it mainly :).

Read full topic

item.title: Script manager and Random manager
item.dc:creator: @ownagesbot ownagesbot
item.description:
@ownagesbot wrote:

I don’t claim to know anything about RS2. But a ‘possible’ solution for randoms could be the following. However, I know nothing about randoms and how they work.

But consider this, you most likely hook events in your client/bot, so why not use them to your advantage, assuming every random has a trigger, use this to call the appropriate random.

In your Random class (I assume this will be like Script), aswell as having the abstract run() method, perhaps also have a getTrigger() method. (The same way a script may have a getCommand() method). When the bot loads, load each class name and trigger into a HashMap.

Upon an event, before handling, check that event isn’t a Random trigger. Perhaps something like the following would be appropriate:

public void OnServerMessage(String msg) { if(!checkForRandom(msg)) handleServerMessage(msg); } public boolean checkForRandom(String trigger) { String clazz; clazz = hashmap.get(trigger); if(clazz != null) { startRandom(clazz); return true; } return false; }
Again, like I said, I don’t know anything about RS2/Randoms, so its quite likely that not all randoms are as simple as asking a user questions etc. But maybe you could do something similar.

Read full topic

item.title: Script manager and Random manager
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

If possible, figure out how to hook the actual random “event” (literally) in the client and respond to it.

Also, Mopman is right.

Read full topic

item.title: Script manager and Random manager
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Probably going to get sighed at for this but “it doesn’t matter”.

IMO, its one of those self-mastabatory problems that people invent simply to have something to ponder, and doesn’t actually matter in the context of real software development.

Don’t mean to squash discussion though, just wanted to say to people who stump on development over things like this “just make it work, then optimise it”.

Or something. I forgot wth i was on about now

Read full topic
